Universality of an impurity in a Bose-Einstein condensate

Shuhei M. Yoshida Department of Physics, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo 113-0033, Japan School of Physics and Astronomy, Monash University, Victoria 3800, Australia    Shimpei Endo School of Physics and Astronomy, Monash University, Victoria 3800, Australia    Jesper Levinsen School of Physics and Astronomy, Monash University, Victoria 3800, Australia    Meera M. Parish School of Physics and Astronomy, Monash University, Victoria 3800, Australia
Abstract

Universality is a powerful concept in physics, allowing one to construct physical descriptions of systems that are independent of the precise microscopic details or energy scales. A prime example is the Fermi gas with unitarity limited interactions, whose universal properties are relevant to systems ranging from atomic gases at microkelvin temperatures to the inner crust of neutron stars. Here we address the question of whether unitary Bose systems can possess a similar universality. We consider the simplest strongly interacting Bose system, where we have an impurity particle (“polaron”) resonantly interacting with a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC). Focusing on the ground state of the equal-mass system, we use a variational wave function for the polaron that includes up to three Bogoliubov excitations of the BEC, thus allowing us to capture both Efimov trimers and associated tetramers. Unlike the Fermi case, we find that the length scale associated with Efimov trimers (i.e., the three-body parameter) can strongly affect the polaron’s behaviour, even at boson densities where there are no well-defined Efimov states. However, by comparing our results with recent quantum Monte Carlo calculations, we argue that the polaron energy is a universal function of the Efimov three-body parameter for sufficiently low boson densities. We further support this conclusion by showing that the energies of the deepest bound Efimov trimers and tetramers at unitarity are universally related to one another, regardless of the microscopic model. On the other hand, we find that the quasiparticle residue and effective mass sensitively depend on the coherence length ξ𝜉\xi of the BEC, with the residue tending to zero as ξ𝜉\xi diverges, in a manner akin to the orthogonality catastrophe.

I Introduction

Quantum gases are expected to exhibit universal thermodynamic and dynamical properties when the scattering length a→±∞→𝑎plus-or-minusa\to\pm\infty and the interparticle spacing greatly exceeds the range of the interactions. Here, the large separation of length scales implies that the unitary gas is independent of an interaction length scale, thus making it insensitive to its microscopic properties. This scenario exists for the two-component Fermi gas at unitarity Randeria et al. (2012), where highly controlled cold-atom experiments have recently determined its universal equation of state Ku et al. (2012); Nascimbène et al. (2010); Horikoshi et al. (2010), pairing correlations Partridge et al. (2005); Stewart et al. (2008); Schirotzek et al. (2008); Inada et al. (2008); Veeravalli et al. (2008); Navon et al. (2010); Stewart et al. (2010); Kuhnle et al. (2010) and transport properties Cao et al. (2011). Moreover, Bose gases in the unitary regime are now also being experimentally probed using ultracold atomic gases Makotyn et al. (2014); Hu et al. (2016); Jørgensen et al. (2016); Fletcher et al. (2017); Lopes et al. (2017); Klauss et al. (2017); Eigen et al. (2017). However, it remains an open question whether the unitary Bose system can also display universal behavior that has relevance to a range of different physical systems.

In contrast to the Fermi case, bosonic systems at unitarity always support few-body Efimov bound states Efimov (1970); Braaten and Hammer (2006); Kraemer et al. (2006); Naidon and Endo (2017); Greene et al. (2017); D’Incao (2017), whose energy and size depend on short-distance parameters such as the interaction range r𝑟r. Thus, there is an additional interaction length scale that can impact the behavior of the unitary Bose system and potentially make it sensitive to microscopic details. Indeed, the deepest bound trimers and larger few-body clusters typically cannot be universally related to each other without invoking a specific model for the short-range interactions Naidon and Endo (2017); Greene et al. (2017).

To investigate the universality of a Bose system at unitarity, we consider an impurity immersed in a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC), where the boson-impurity interactions can be tuned to unitarity, while the rest of the system remains weakly interacting. This so-called “Bose polaron” has received much theoretical attention Tempere et al. (2009); Rath and Schmidt (2013); Li and Das Sarma (2014); Shashi et al. (2014); Christensen et al. (2015); Levinsen et al. (2015); Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2015); Grusdt et al. (2015); Grusdt and Demler (2015); Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2016); Shchadilova et al. (2016a); Loft et al. (2017); Grusdt et al. (2017); Sun et al. (2017); Lampo et al. (2017) and has very recently been observed in cold-atom experiments Hu et al. (2016); Jørgensen et al. (2016). Moreover, it has been extended to impurities with more complex internal structure Schmidt and Lemeshko (2015); Schmidt et al. (2016); Camargo et al. (2017), and it has potential relevance to polaron problems in solid-state systems — for instance, the limit of weak impurity-boson interactions can be directly mapped to the Fröhlich model Tempere et al. (2009); Rentrop et al. (2016). The Bose polaron is a promising system in which to search for universal behavior, since the Efimov trimers consisting of the impurity and two bosons are orders of magnitude larger than the short distance scale r𝑟r (provided the impurity mass is not too small) Wang et al. (2012a); Blume and Yan (2014). If we parameterize the size of the deepest Efimov trimer by |a−|subscript𝑎|a_{-}|, where a−subscript𝑎a_{-} is the scattering length at which the trimer crosses the three-atom continuum (see Fig. 1), then the hierarchy of length scales at unitarity is r≪n−1/3≪|a−|much-less-than𝑟superscript𝑛13much-less-thansubscript𝑎r\ll n^{-1/3}\ll|a_{-}| for the typical densities n𝑛n in experiment Hu et al. (2016); Jørgensen et al. (2016). This suggests that there is a regime where Efimov physics is irrelevant, such that the ground-state properties of the polaron only depend on the density, like in the case of an impurity resonantly interacting with a Fermi gas Chevy (2006); Combescot and Giraud (2008); Prokof’ev and Svistunov (2008); Vlietinck et al. (2013); Massignan et al. (2014).

In this paper, we address this question using impurities that have a mass equal to that of the bosons — a situation which has already been realized in the 39K atomic gas experiments in Aarhus Jørgensen et al. (2016). We first investigate the few-body limit, and determine the Efimov trimer and associated tetramer states that involve the impurity. For vanishing boson-boson interactions, we show that the ratios of the binding energies for the deepest bound states are universal, unlike the identical-boson case. We then include this Efimov physics in the many-body system by constructing a variational wave function for the ground-state Bose polaron which recovers both three- and four-body equations in the limit of zero density. Strikingly, we find that the polaron properties at unitarity sensitively depend on the Efimov scale |a−|subscript𝑎|a_{-}|, even in the regime where |a−|subscript𝑎|a_{-}| far exceeds the interparticle spacing. However, we show that the ground-state polaron energy is a universal function of n1/3​|a−|superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎n^{1/3}|a_{-}| that is model independent in the regime n1/3​r≪1much-less-thansuperscript𝑛13𝑟1n^{1/3}r\ll 1. We corroborate this finding by comparing our results with recent quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) calculations Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2015, 2016).

In the non-universal, high-density limit n1/3​r≫1much-greater-thansuperscript𝑛13𝑟1n^{1/3}r\gg 1, we consider the case of a narrow Feshbach resonance and we derive perturbative expressions for the polaron energy and contact at unitarity. This allows us to demonstrate, for the first time, that the Bose polaron at unitarity can be thermodynamically stable even in the limit of vanishing boson-boson interactions. On the other hand, we find that the quasiparticle residue and effective mass sensitively depend on the BEC coherence length. For the case of an ideal BEC, the effective mass converges to a finite value as we increase the number of excitations of the condensate, while the residue vanishes in a manner reminiscent of the orthogonality catastrophe for a static impurity in a Fermi gas Anderson (1967).

II Model and variational approach

We consider an impurity atom immersed in a weakly interacting homogeneous Bose-Einstein condensate at zero temperature. The interactions in the medium are characterised by the boson-boson scattering length aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}}, and we thus require n0​aB3≪1much-less-thansubscript𝑛0superscriptsubscript𝑎B31n_{0}a_{\text{B}}^{3}\ll 1, with n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} the condensate density (which essentially equals the total density n𝑛n in this regime). This allows us to treat both the ground state and the excitations of the BEC within Bogoliubov theory Fetter and Walecka (1971). Note that we always implicitly assume aB>0subscript𝑎B0a_{\text{B}}>0 to ensure the stability of the condensate.

The presence of the impurity in the medium adds two length scales associated with the impurity-boson interaction. The first of these is the scattering length a𝑎a between the impurity and a boson from the medium. We disregard this length scale since we will focus on the strong-coupling unitary regime close to a Feshbach resonance, where |a|𝑎|a| greatly exceeds all other length scales, i.e., we generally consider 1/a=01𝑎01/a=0. Here, we assume short-range contact interactions, which is well realized in current cold-atom experiments.

The second additional length scale is the so-called three-body parameter, which characterizes the size of the smallest (ground-state) Efimov trimer consisting of two bosons and the impurity. To demonstrate the model independence of our results, we fix this Efimov length scale in two different ways:

  • •

    r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model — we introduce an effective range r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}, which directly relates the three-body parameter to the two-body interaction Petrov (2004)

  • •

    ΛΛ\Lambda-model — we take r0→0→subscript𝑟00r_{0}\to 0 and instead apply an explicit ultraviolet cutoff ΛΛ\Lambda to the momenta involved in Efimov physics, which is equivalent to including a three-body repulsion Bedaque et al. (1999)

As we explicitly show in Section III, for an impurity of the same mass as the medium atoms — the scenario considered here — the precise manner of regularizing Efimov physics is unimportant owing to the large separation of scales between the short-range physics and Efimov physics.

Given the above considerations, we model the system using a two-channel description of the Feshbach resonance Timmermans et al. (1999), which corresponds to the Hamiltonian (setting ℏPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar and the volume to 1):

To explore the ground-state properties of the unitary Bose polaron, we apply the variational principle, using a wave function consisting of terms |ψN⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝑁\left|{\psi_{N}}\right> with an increasing number N𝑁N of Bogoliubov modes excited from the condensate by the impurity:

with |Φ⟩ketΦ\left|{\Phi}\right> the ground state wave function of the weakly interacting BEC. Including up to three excitations allows us to investigate the effect of both Efimov trimers and tetramers on the unitary Bose polaron. This goes beyond previous works on the Bose polaron: The effect of dressing the impurity by a single excitation was investigated in Ref. Rath and Schmidt (2013) using a T𝑇T-matrix approach and in Ref. Li and Das Sarma (2014) with a variational approach. Furthermore, two of us previously used two-excitation dressing to investigate the relationship between polaronic and Efimov physics Levinsen et al. (2015), as well as to successfully compare with the experimentally obtained polaron spectral function Jørgensen et al. (2016) (see also Ref. Parish and Levinsen (2016)).

To investigate the properties of the ground-state Bose polaron, we determine the variational parameters by the stationary condition ∂α∗,γ∗⟨Ψ|(H^−E)|Ψ⟩=0subscriptsuperscript𝛼∗superscript𝛾∗quantum-operator-productΨ^𝐻𝐸Ψ0\partial_{\alpha^{\ast},\gamma^{\ast}}\left\langle{\Psi}\right|(\hat{H}-E)\left|{\Psi}\right>=0, where the energy E𝐸E can be viewed as the Lagrange multiplier ensuring normalization. This yields a set of coupled equations, from which we can eliminate the α𝛼\alpha coefficients and obtain coupled integral equations for the γ𝛾\gamma’s only. The resulting equations are given in Appendix A. In the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model, we keep the effective range r0subscript𝑟0r_{0} in the two-body interaction, while in the ΛΛ\Lambda-model, we set r0=0subscript𝑟00r_{0}=0 and apply the cutoff ΛΛ\Lambda to the momenta in the γ𝛾\gamma coefficients.

III Universal few-body Efimov states

Before proceeding to the many-body polaron physics, it is important to first discuss the few-body limit since — as we shall explicitly demonstrate in Section IV — this plays a crucial role in understanding the polaron properties. To determine the few-body spectrum, we use wave functions of the form (5) in the limit n→0→𝑛0n\to 0, such that |Φ⟩ketΦ\left|{\Phi}\right> now corresponds to the Fock vacuum. Here, the state |ψN⟩ketsubscript𝜓𝑁\left|{\psi_{N}}\right> with N𝑁N excitations is identified as a few-body state containing N𝑁N bosons and the impurity. Consequently, the varational approach is exact and the sectors of different particle numbers completely decouple. Ignoring the trivial equation arising from the single-particle problem, the resulting few-body equations take the form

which may be obtained as the zero-density limit of the polaron equations in Appendix A. Here we have defined ϵ𝐤1​𝐤2≡ϵ𝐤1+ϵ𝐤2+ϵ𝐤1+𝐤2subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝐤1subscript𝐤2subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝐤1subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝐤2subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝐤1subscript𝐤2\epsilon_{{\bf k}_{1}{\bf k}_{2}}\equiv\epsilon_{{\bf k}_{1}}+\epsilon_{{\bf k}_{2}}+\epsilon_{{\bf k}_{1}+{\bf k}_{2}} and ϵ𝐤1​𝐤2​𝐪≡ϵ𝐤1+ϵ𝐤2+ϵ𝐪+ϵ𝐤1+𝐤2+𝐪subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝐤1subscript𝐤2𝐪subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝐤1subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝐤2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐪subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝐤1subscript𝐤2𝐪\epsilon_{{\bf k}_{1}{\bf k}_{2}{\bf q}}\equiv\epsilon_{{\bf k}_{1}}+\epsilon_{{\bf k}_{2}}+\epsilon_{{\bf q}}+\epsilon_{{\bf k}_{1}+{\bf k}_{2}+{\bf q}}, while 𝒯0subscript𝒯0{\cal T}_{0} is the vacuum two-body T𝑇T-matrix,

𝒯0−1​(E,𝐤)superscriptsubscript𝒯01𝐸𝐤\displaystyle{\cal T}_{0}^{-1}(E,{\bf k}) =m4​π​a−m2​r08​π​(E−ϵ𝐤d)−m324​π​ϵ𝐤d−E−i​0.absent𝑚4𝜋𝑎superscript𝑚2subscript𝑟08𝜋𝐸subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑑𝐤superscript𝑚324𝜋subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑑𝐤𝐸𝑖0\displaystyle=\frac{m}{4\pi a}-\frac{m^{2}r_{0}}{8\pi}(E-\epsilon^{d}_{{\bf k}})-\frac{m^{\frac{3}{2}}}{4\pi}\sqrt{\epsilon^{d}_{\bf k}-E-i0}. (9)

Equation (6) gives the condition for a two-body bound state, while the solutions of Eqs. (7) and (8) yield, respectively, the trimer spectrum and associated tetramers Pricoupenko (2011). Note that boson-boson interactions are neglected in this limit, since they are only included via a density-dependent mean-field shift in the boson chemical potential. However, this approximation is reasonable when the Efimov states are insensitive to aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}}, i.e., when the microscopic length scale determining the three-body parameter greatly exceeds aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}}.

In Figure 1, we show the spectrum of bound states obtained by solving Eqs. (6–8) within the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model. For positive scattering length, a single two-body bound dimer exists, with energy

εB=−(1−2​r0/a−1)2m​r02,subscript𝜀𝐵superscript12subscript𝑟0𝑎12𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑟02\displaystyle\varepsilon_{B}=-\frac{\left(\sqrt{1-2r_{0}/a}-1\right)^{2}}{mr_{0}^{2}}, (10)

as found by solving Eq. (6). The three-body problem described by Eq. (7) is distinctly different: For strong interactions, the impurity and two bosons can form an infinite series of three-body bound states, even in the absence of the two-body bound state. Remarkably, these so-called Efimov trimers Efimov (1970, 1973) satisfy a discrete scaling symmetry whereby the energy E𝐸E of one trimer can be mapped onto the next via the discrete transformation E→λ0−2​l​E→𝐸superscriptsubscript𝜆02𝑙𝐸E\to\lambda_{0}^{-2l}E and a→λ0l​a→𝑎superscriptsubscript𝜆0𝑙𝑎a\to\lambda_{0}^{l}a, with l𝑙l integer and λ0subscript𝜆0\lambda_{0} a scaling parameter that depends on the particular three-body problem (for reviews, see Refs. Braaten and Hammer (2006); Naidon and Endo (2017); Greene et al. (2017); D’Incao (2017)). In our case of two non-interacting identical bosons with the same mass as the third particle, the scaling factor is found from a transcendental equation to be λ0=eπ/s0≃1986.1subscript𝜆0superscript𝑒𝜋subscript𝑠0similar-to-or-equals1986.1\lambda_{0}=e^{\pi/s_{0}}\simeq 1986.1 Efimov (1973). Due to this large scaling factor, we only show the two lowest trimer states in the figure (indeed, for realistic experimental parameters, the size of the first excited Efimov trimer is of order 1cm!).

Below the ground-state Efimov trimer, we predict the existence of two tetramer states, even at unitarity (see Fig. 1). This mirrors previous results for four identical bosons, where it was found, both theoretically Hammer and Platter (2007); von Stecher et al. (2009); Hadizadeh et al. (2011); Deltuva (2011) and experimentally Ferlaino et al. (2009), that there are two lower-lying tetramers associated with the ground-state trimer. The present scenario more closely resembles studies of a light atom resonantly interacting with three identical heavy atoms Blume and Yan (2014); Wang et al. (2012b); Schmickler et al. (2017). Our findings are generally consistent with the results of these previous works, although no excited tetramer was reported for small mass imbalance 111We have not investigated tetramer states tied to the excited Efimov trimer, but we expect that they will exist as resonant states embedded in the atom-trimer continuum, as is the case for identical bosons Deltuva (2011); von Stecher (2011).. Note that, within our theory, we do not require an additional length scale to fix the positions of the tetramers relative to the Efimov trimers Hadizadeh et al. (2011).

A crucial point is that the few-body physics described here is essentially universal, in the sense that the entire spectrum is independent of the details of the short-range physics. This universality originates from the large separation of scales between the short-distance physics, characterized here by the effective range r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}, and the typical size of the ground-state Efimov trimer. The latter may be conveniently characterized by the “critical” scattering length a−subscript𝑎a_{-} at which the trimer crosses into the three-atom continuum. In our model, we have a−/r0≃2467similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑎subscript𝑟02467a_{-}/r_{0}\simeq 2467 222This number had a typo in Ref. Levinsen et al. (2015) which did not affect any of the other results of that paper. (see Table 1 for a summary of the length scales and energy scales associated with Efimov physics). This large ratio ensures that the energy of the ground-state Efimov trimer at unitarity is far smaller than that required to probe the short-range physics. Indeed, we see that the ratio of critical scattering lengths for the excited and ground-state trimers, i.e., a−(1)/a−≃1991similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑎1991a_{-}^{(1)}/a_{-}\simeq 1991, is very close to the predicted scaling factor of 1986.11986.11986.1. Likewise, at unitarity, the ratio of the ground-state trimer energy to that of the excited state is E−/E−(1)≃(1986.1)2similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝐸superscriptsubscript𝐸1superscript1986.12E_{-}/E_{-}^{(1)}\simeq(1986.1)^{2}, i.e., it matches the universal prediction to 5 significant digits. This is in remarkable contrast to the situation for three identical bosons, where deviations from the universal scaling factor of 22.7 are usually on the order of 10-20% due to finite-range corrections Huang et al. (2014); Braaten and Hammer (2006); Naidon and Endo (2017).

To test the model independence of the few-body physics, we also consider the ΛΛ\Lambda-model, where r0=0subscript𝑟00r_{0}=0 and we apply an explicit cutoff ΛΛ\Lambda to the momentum sums in the three- and four-body equations (7–8). Here we find that after fixing the three-body parameter, the spectrum is essentially indistinguishable from that in Fig. 1, in the sense that the differences are within the thickness of the lines 333The exception to this expected universality is the crossing of the ground-state trimer with the atom-dimer continuum (not shown in Fig. 1). This crossing is in general known to be the least universal aspect of Efimov trimers, as it corresponds to the largest energy scale. We indeed find that the ground state trimer crossing is at a∗/|a−|≃4.86×10−4similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑎subscript𝑎4.86superscript104a_{*}/|a_{-}|\simeq 4.86\times 10^{-4} in the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model and at a∗/|a−|≃5.58×10−4similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑎subscript𝑎5.58superscript104a_{*}/|a_{-}|\simeq 5.58\times 10^{-4} in the ΛΛ\Lambda-model, neither of which quite fits the universal prediction: a∗/|a−|≃0.72418​e−π/s0=3.6×10−4similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑎subscript𝑎0.72418superscript𝑒𝜋subscript𝑠03.6superscript104a_{*}/|a_{-}|\simeq 0.72418e^{-\pi/s_{0}}=3.6\times 10^{-4} Helfrich et al. (2010). On the other hand, we find that the first excited trimer, with a∗(1)/|a−|≃0.71similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑎0.71a_{*}^{(1)}/|a_{-}|\simeq 0.71, matches reasonably well. . The agreement between the two models is also evident in the summary of length scales and energy scales in Table 1. Thus, we conclude that our description of the few-body spectrum can be accurately characterized by universal Efimov theory.

Further evidence of the universality of our few-body results is found when comparing the ratio of our ground-state tetramer and trimer energies with recent QMC results Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2015). There, this ratio was reported to be E4​B,−(1)/E−≃9.7similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝐸4B1subscript𝐸9.7E_{\mathrm{4B},-}^{(1)}/E_{-}\simeq 9.7, while we find E4​B,−(1)/E−≃9.35similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝐸4B1subscript𝐸9.35E_{\mathrm{4B},-}^{(1)}/E_{-}\simeq 9.35. Importantly, the QMC calculation used a completely different model involving a hard-sphere boson-boson interaction, characterized by the scattering length aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}}, and attractive square-well interactions between the impurity and the bosons. The range of the square well was taken to be much smaller than aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}}, and consequently the energies of the ground-state Efimov trimer and associated tetramers are set by aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}}. The agreement between the results from the different models also reinforces the point that we do not need a four-body parameter to fix the tetramer relative to the trimer. This is consistent with theoretical results for identical bosons Hammer and Platter (2007); von Stecher et al. (2009); Deltuva (2011) and for heteronuclear systems Blume and Yan (2014); Wang et al. (2012b); Schmickler et al. (2017).

We end this section by contrasting the few-body universality found here with the so-called van der Waals universality of Efimov physics Berninger et al. (2011); Wang et al. (2012c); Naidon et al. (2014a, b); Wang and Julienne (2014). The latter refers to the phenomenon where the Efimov states of various atomic species are universally related to their van der Waals length, e.g., a−≃−(9.1±1.5)​rvdWsimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑎plus-or-minus9.11.5subscript𝑟vdWa_{-}\simeq-(9.1\pm 1.5)r_{\mathrm{vdW}}. This behavior, however, is rather different from that predicted by universal zero-range Efimov theory, in particular for the ground-state trimer. Indeed, the ratio a−(1)/a−≃20.7similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑎20.7a_{-}^{(1)}/a_{-}\simeq 20.7 found in van der Waals universal theory Wang and Julienne (2014) significantly deviates from the universal ratio 22.7, in contrast to the scenario considered here.

IV Polaron energy at unitarity

We now turn to the many-body system and investigate the zero-temperature equation of state for the polaron at unitarity. Since we wish to properly describe Efimov physics within our models, we will focus on the regime where the boson-boson scattering length aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}} is always much smaller than all other length scales. To test the accuracy of our variational approach outlined in Eqs. (4) and (5), we will consider wave functions with up to one, two or three Bogoliubov excitations, corresponding to |ψ0⟩+|ψ1⟩ketsubscript𝜓0ketsubscript𝜓1\left|{\psi_{0}}\right>+\left|{\psi_{1}}\right>, |ψ0⟩+|ψ1⟩+|ψ2⟩ketsubscript𝜓0ketsubscript𝜓1ketsubscript𝜓2\left|{\psi_{0}}\right>+\left|{\psi_{1}}\right>+\left|{\psi_{2}}\right>, and |Ψ⟩ketΨ\left|{\Psi}\right>, respectively. For each model, we will convert the short-distance scale (e.g., r0subscript𝑟0r_{0} or Λ−1superscriptΛ1\Lambda^{-1}) into the dimensionless three-body parameter n1/3​|a−|superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎n^{1/3}|a_{-}| in order to expose the role of universal Efimov physics. The numerical results are displayed in Fig. 2 and, in the following, we analyze the different regimes defined by particle density.

IV.1 Low-density limit

In the limit of vanishing density n1/3​|a−|→0→superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎0n^{1/3}|a_{-}|\to 0, the ground-state polaron energy should reduce to that of the deepest bound few-body cluster. If the polaron variational wave function only includes one Bogoliubov excitation, the largest few-body state it can describe is the dimer, which has zero binding energy at unitarity. Thus, as shown in Fig. 2, we obtain an energy that simply tends to zero with decreasing density, i.e., E=−(4​π​n)2/3/m≃−5.4​n2/3/m𝐸superscript4𝜋𝑛23𝑚similar-to-or-equals5.4superscript𝑛23𝑚E=-(4\pi n)^{2/3}/m\simeq-5.4n^{2/3}/m Rath and Schmidt (2013); Li and Das Sarma (2014). Note that this is independent of the microscopic model we use since the interparticle spacing greatly exceeds any length scale of the impurity-boson interactions.

For polaron wave functions with up to two (three) Bogoliubov excitations, the low-density limit recovers the deepest bound universal trimer (tetramer) state discussed in Sec. III. Here, the density drops out of the problem and we have polaron energy E=−ηm​|a−|2𝐸𝜂𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑎2E=-\frac{\eta}{m|a_{-}|^{2}}, where η𝜂\eta is a universal, model-independent constant that depends on the Efimov cluster size (see Fig. 2).

We also expect there to be larger bound clusters beyond the tetramer, similarly to the case of identical bosons where larger clusters associated with the Efimov effect have been predicted Von Stecher (2010); Gattobigio and Kievsky (2014); Yan and Blume (2015) and, indeed, experimentally observed Zenesini et al. (2013). For the impurity case, recent QMC calculations already demonstrate the existence of a pentamer with η≃300similar-to-or-equals𝜂300\eta\simeq 300 Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2015). However, since there is a high-energy cutoff in the problem (e.g., set by ΛΛ\Lambda or r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}), the system cannot support arbitrarily deeply bound Efimov clusters, and the deepest bound state should be universal as long as η≪106much-less-than𝜂superscript106\eta\ll 10^{6}. Indeed, as suggested by the QMC calculations Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2015), it is possible that there is no bound cluster larger than the pentamer for the equal-mass impurity case. Firstly, the pairwise attraction between the impurity and the bosons scales with N𝑁N rather than N​(N−1)𝑁𝑁1N(N-1), unlike the case for N𝑁N identical bosons Greene et al. (2017), so larger bound states will be less favored. Secondly, an effective short-range repulsion between bosons could mean that the pentamer has a closed-shell structure, where any additional bosons must occupy higher energy orbitals, similar to what has been argued for mass-imbalanced fermions Bazak and Petrov (2017); Bazak (2017). Such an effective repulsion naturally emerges in both the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}- and the ΛΛ\Lambda-models: In the former, this arises from the fact that only one boson at a time can occupy the closed-channel dimer, while in the latter it is due to the three-body cut-off being equivalent to a three-body repulsion Bedaque et al. (1999).

From the above considerations, it is reasonable to conclude that the low-density limit is universal. Moreover, since there is a maximum size to the deepest bound Efimov cluster, we expect the polaron energy to have a well-defined thermodynamic limit, where m​E/n2/3𝑚𝐸superscript𝑛23mE/n^{2/3} is finite for non-zero density.

IV.2 High-density limit

To further support the claim that the polaron energy is finite at unitarity, we consider the opposite limit of high density, n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty. Here, the interparticle spacing becomes smaller than the range of the interactions and thus the system will depend on the microscopic details of the model. However, in the case of the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model, it allows us to perform a controlled perturbative expansion in the inter-channel coupling g𝑔g (or, equivalently, 1/n1/3​|r0|1superscript𝑛13subscript𝑟01/n^{1/3}|r_{0}|) at unitarity Gurarie and Radzihovsky (2007). Physically, this corresponds to the limit of a narrow Feshbach resonance, a scenario which has already been successfully investigated for an impurity in a Fermi sea, both theoretically Massignan (2012); Trefzger and Castin (2012); Qi and Zhai (2012) and experimentally Kohstall et al. (2012); Cetina et al. (2016).

Our starting point is the self-energy of the unitary Bose polaron, which, in the limit g→0→𝑔0g\to 0 and aB→0→subscript𝑎B0a_{\text{B}}\to 0, consists of the lowest order diagrams shown in Fig. 3. Such diagrams are included in the self-consistent T𝑇T-matrix approach to the Bose polaron Rath and Schmidt (2013). For an impurity with momentum 𝐩𝐩{\bf p} and frequency ω𝜔\omega, the self-energy in this limit is explicitly

Σ​(𝐩,ω)Σ𝐩𝜔\displaystyle\Sigma({\bf p},\omega) ≃n0​g2ω−ϵ𝐩d+n0​g4(ω−ϵ𝐩d)2×\displaystyle\simeq\frac{n_{0}g^{2}}{\omega-\epsilon_{\bf p}^{d}}+\frac{n_{0}g^{4}}{(\omega-\epsilon_{\bf p}^{d})^{2}}\times
∑𝐤[1ω−ϵ𝐤+𝐩−ϵ𝐤−n0​g2ω−ϵ𝐤+𝐩d−ϵ𝐤+12​ϵ𝐤],subscript𝐤delimited-[]1𝜔subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐤𝐩subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐤subscript𝑛0superscript𝑔2𝜔superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐤𝐩𝑑subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐤12subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐤\displaystyle\sum_{\bf k}\left[\frac{1}{\omega-\epsilon_{{\bf k}+{\bf p}}-\epsilon_{{\bf k}}-\frac{n_{0}g^{2}}{\omega-\epsilon_{{\bf k}+{\bf p}}^{d}-\epsilon_{{\bf k}}}}+\frac{1}{2\epsilon_{{\bf k}}}\right], (12)

where the first and second terms correspond to the diagrams in Fig. 3(a) and (b), respectively. The ground-state polaron energy is then determined by taking the zero-momentum pole of the impurity propagator, which gives E=Σ​(𝟎,E)𝐸Σ0𝐸E=\Sigma({\bf 0},E). Note that we must include self-energy insertions in the impurity propagator even at lowest order (see Fig. 3), since the we cannot simply take ω=0𝜔0\omega=0 at the pole when aB→0→subscript𝑎B0a_{\text{B}}\to 0. This is in contrast to previous perturbative treatments of the weakly interacting Bose polaron which focussed on aB>0subscript𝑎B0a_{\text{B}}>0 Christensen et al. (2015).

In the regime of weak boson-boson interactions, where n​aB3≪aB/|r0|≪1much-less-than𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑎B3subscript𝑎Bsubscript𝑟0much-less-than1na_{\text{B}}^{3}\ll a_{\text{B}}/|r_{0}|\ll 1, we obtain the ground-state polaron energy

E≃−1m​8​π​n|r0|+1m​37​(8​π​n|r0|5)1/4.similar-to-or-equals𝐸1𝑚8𝜋𝑛subscript𝑟01𝑚37superscript8𝜋𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑟0514\displaystyle E\simeq-\frac{1}{m}\sqrt{\frac{8\pi n}{|r_{0}|}}+\frac{1}{m}\sqrt{\frac{3}{7}}\left(\frac{8\pi n}{|r_{0}|^{5}}\right)^{1/4}. (13)

This demonstrates that the energy is well-defined and bounded from below in this limit, even when the boson-boson interactions are vanishingly small. Such behavior arises from the fact that only one boson at a time can scatter into the closed channel, thus producing an effective boson-boson repulsion that restricts the density of bosons that can cluster around the impurity. As shown in Fig. 2, the perturbative expression correctly reproduces the energy for the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model in the high-density limit. Note that the one-excitation wave function only captures the leading order term in Fig. 3(a), while the wave functions with two or three excitations correctly describe the next order correction in 1/n1/3​|r0|1superscript𝑛13subscript𝑟01/n^{1/3}|r_{0}|.

In the case of the ΛΛ\Lambda-model, the high-density limit corresponds to n1/3/Λ→∞→superscript𝑛13Λn^{1/3}/\Lambda\to\infty, which is equivalent to taking the cutoff ΛΛ\Lambda to zero. Therefore, within our variational approach, only two-body correlations survive and we obtain the equations for the wave function with one excitation (see Appendix A). For vanishing boson-boson interactions, this yields E=−(4​π​n)2/3/m𝐸superscript4𝜋𝑛23𝑚E=-(4\pi n)^{2/3}/m, which is the polaron energy of the one-excitation wave function across all densities, as shown in Fig. 2.

IV.3 Many-body universal regime

In the intermediate regime r≪n−1/3≪|a−|much-less-than𝑟superscript𝑛13much-less-thansubscript𝑎r\ll n^{-1/3}\ll|a_{-}| (where r𝑟r can represent |r0|subscript𝑟0|r_{0}| or Λ−1superscriptΛ1\Lambda^{-1}), the interparticle distance is well separated from all length scales associated with the interactions. If the medium were fermionic rather than bosonic, then the polaron energy at unitarity would be a universal value that only depends on the medium density, i.e., Epol≃−4.6​n2/3/msimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝐸pol4.6superscript𝑛23𝑚E_{\rm pol}\simeq-4.6n^{2/3}/m Chevy (2006). Remarkably, for the Bose polaron, we see in Fig. 2 that the energy strongly depends on n1/3​|a−|superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎n^{1/3}|a_{-}| at intermediate densities. This suggests that there exist resonant three-body interactions, such that there are strong three-body correlations in the system even when the trimer binding energy is comparatively small.

Even though the energy of the Bose polaron cannot be assigned a universal value at unitarity, we argue that it is, in fact, a universal function of n1/3​|a−|superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎n^{1/3}|a_{-}| away from the high-density regime. We have previously argued that the low-density limit of the polaron energy universally depends on n1/3​|a−|superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎n^{1/3}|a_{-}| due to the universal behavior of the few-body states demonstrated in Sec. III. Here, for the intermediate density regime shown in Fig. 4, we see that different microscopic models of the Bose polaron can essentially be collapsed onto the same curve when the ground-state energy is plotted versus n1/3​|a−|superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎n^{1/3}|a_{-}|. In particular, both the results for the ΛΛ\Lambda- and the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-models are consistent with the QMC calculation from Ref. Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2016) when Eq. (11) is used to plot the QMC data in terms of the Efimov three-body parameter. This demonstrates that the polaron energy can be universally described in terms of n01/3​|a−|superscriptsubscript𝑛013subscript𝑎n_{0}^{1/3}|a_{-}|, regardless of the microscopic details. Furthermore, it suggests that our variational approach with three Bogoliubov excitations captures the dominant correlations in the full many-body problem, and that the Efimov three-body parameter plays a more important role in the polaron energy than the coherence length of the condensate (see Appendix B). We emphasize that our comparison in Fig. 4 constitutes a complete reinterpretation of the QMC results of Ref. Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2016), since that work did not consider the possibility that the variation of the polaron energy with boson-boson interaction was due to Efimov physics.

V Characterization of the polaron

Having shown that the polaron energy is a universal function of n1/3​|a−|superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎n^{1/3}|a_{-}| for sufficiently low densities, we now turn to the other quasiparticle properties which characterize the polaron: the residue, effective mass, and contact. We will generally focus on the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model, which is the more physical model and which allows a perturbative analysis in the high-density limit.

V.1 Residue

The residue Z𝑍Z is the squared overlap of the polaron wave function with the non-interacting state c0†​|Φ⟩superscriptsubscript𝑐0†ketΦc_{0}^{\dagger}\left|{\Phi}\right>. Making reference to the wave function in Eq. (5), this is

Z=|α0|2,𝑍superscriptsubscript𝛼02\displaystyle Z=|\alpha_{0}|^{2}, (14)

where we assume ⟨Ψ|Ψ⟩=1inner-productΨΨ1\left<\Psi|\Psi\right>=1 for normalization (see Appendix C). The residue can be accessed directly in experiment; indeed, in the case of the Fermi polaron it has been measured using both radio-frequency spectroscopy Schirotzek et al. (2009) and Rabi oscillations Kohstall et al. (2012).

In Fig. 5 we show our results for the polaron residue at unitarity as a function of the three-body parameter, where the boson-boson interactions are taken to be vanishingly small. We find that there are clear differences between the results depending on the number of Bogoliubov excitations used in the variational approach, and also between the different models. Within the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model the residue takes the value 1/2 in the high-density regime where the polaron wave function is an equal superposition of the impurity and the closed-channel dimer. However, while the residue within the one-excitation approximation is seen to increase from 1/2 to 2/3 with increasing density, we observe a rapid decrease of Z𝑍Z towards the low-density regime when including several excitations. On the other hand, for the ΛΛ\Lambda-model, the residue is 2/3 if we consider only one Bogoliubov excitation. By increasing the number of Bogoliubov excitations, it is suppressed not only in the few-body dominated regime, but also in the high-density limit, where the residue takes the values 1/3 and 1/9, respectively, when two and three excitations are taken into account. Thus, unlike the energy, the polaron residue does not appear to converge to a universal function of the three-body parameter.

The origin of this behavior can be understood within perturbation theory for the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model in the high-density limit. Considering again the diagrams in Fig. 3 and the explicit expression for the self-energy in Eq. (12), we find at small g𝑔g:

Z−1superscript𝑍1\displaystyle Z^{-1} =1−∂Σ​(𝟎,ω)∂ω|ω=Eabsent1evaluated-atΣ0𝜔𝜔𝜔𝐸\displaystyle=1-\left.\frac{\partial\Sigma({\bf 0},\omega)}{\partial\omega}\right|_{\omega=E}
≃2−37​2(8​π​n​|r0|3)1/4+L|r0|,similar-to-or-equalsabsent2372superscript8𝜋𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑟0314𝐿subscript𝑟0\displaystyle\simeq 2-\sqrt{\frac{3}{7}}\frac{2}{(8\pi n|r_{0}|^{3})^{1/4}}+\frac{L}{|r_{0}|}, (15)

where L𝐿L is a low-energy length scale that provides an infrared cutoff of low momenta. In the thermodynamic limit, this is set by the coherence length of the BEC, i.e., we have L∝ξproportional-to𝐿𝜉L\propto\xi. Thus, we find that the residue vanishes when the coherence length ξ→∞→𝜉\xi\to\infty, and consequently the polaron wave function is orthogonal to the non-interacting impurity state in the case of an ideal BEC. This feature cannot properly be captured within our variational approach, since this requires an infinite number of Bogoliubov excitations; hence the observed lack of convergence in Fig. 5. On the other hand, when aB≠0subscript𝑎B0a_{\text{B}}\neq 0 we find that the wave functions with two and three excitations both give the same leading order correction to Z𝑍Z:

Z−12∝aB|r0|,proportional-to𝑍12subscript𝑎Bsubscript𝑟0\displaystyle Z-\frac{1}{2}\propto\sqrt{\frac{a_{\text{B}}}{|r_{0}|}}, (16)

in the limit n1/3​aB≪1much-less-thansuperscript𝑛13subscript𝑎B1n^{1/3}a_{\text{B}}\ll 1 and n1/3​|r0|→∞→superscript𝑛13subscript𝑟0n^{1/3}|r_{0}|\to\infty 555The high-density expansion for Z𝑍Z at finite aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}} can, in principle, be calculated using an approach similar to that in Ref. Christensen et al. (2015). However, such a lengthy perturbative analysis goes beyond the scope of this work.. Thus, in this case, the residue is finite and initially increases with decreasing |r0|subscript𝑟0|r_{0}|. Note, however, that the residue always vanishes in the low-density regime, as shown in Fig. 5, since the polaron evolves into a few-body bound state which has zero overlap with the non-interacting impurity state.

The simultaneous convergence of the energy but suppression of the residue in the ideal BEC arises from the fact that the impurity affects the condensate at arbitrarily large distances and thus excites an infinite number of low-energy modes in the condensate. This result is akin to the orthogonality catastrophe for a static impurity in a Fermi gas. Indeed, in that case, the orthogonality of the interacting and non-interacting impurity wave functions is also apparent in perturbation theory, already at lowest order beyond mean-field theory Anderson (1995). We also note that the vanishing residue of the Bose polaron is not confined to the strongly interacting impurity at unitarity: Even for weak impurity-boson interactions, the residue of the attractive polaron was found within perturbation theory to approach zero as 1/ξ1𝜉1/\xi when aB→0→subscript𝑎B0a_{\text{B}}\to 0 Christensen et al. (2015).

V.2 Effective mass

The interactions between the impurity and the bosonic medium also modify the mobility of the impurity and give rise to an effective mass m∗superscript𝑚m^{*}. This can be derived from the impurity’s self-energy as follows:

mm∗𝑚superscript𝑚\displaystyle\frac{m}{m^{*}} =Z​[1+m​∂2Σ​(𝐪,E)∂q2|q=0].absent𝑍delimited-[]1evaluated-at𝑚superscript2Σ𝐪𝐸superscript𝑞2𝑞0\displaystyle=Z\left[1+m\left.\frac{\partial^{2}\Sigma({\bf q},E)}{\partial q^{2}}\right|_{q=0}\right]. (17)

Note that this gives m∗=msuperscript𝑚𝑚m^{*}=m for the non-interacting impurity state, as required. Our calculation of m∗superscript𝑚m^{*} within the variational approach is described in Appendix C, and the results for aB→0→subscript𝑎B0a_{\text{B}}\to 0 at unitarity are plotted in Fig. 6. Due to the complexity of the calculation, we restrict ourselves to wave functions with up to two Bogoliubov excitations.

For the case of an ideal BEC, we have residue Z→0→𝑍0Z\to 0, and thus one might conclude from Eq. (17) that the effective mass diverges. However, if we once again consider the high-density limit of the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model and use the self-energy in Eq. (12), we obtain

mm∗𝑚superscript𝑚\displaystyle\frac{m}{m^{*}} ≃Z​(32−37​1(8​π​n​|r0|3)1/4+α​L|r0|),similar-to-or-equalsabsent𝑍32371superscript8𝜋𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑟0314𝛼𝐿subscript𝑟0\displaystyle\simeq Z\left(\frac{3}{2}-\sqrt{\frac{3}{7}}\frac{1}{(8\pi n|r_{0}|^{3})^{1/4}}+\alpha\frac{L}{|r_{0}|}\right), (18)

where α𝛼\alpha is a constant that must be determined from a proper finite-aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}} perturbative analysis. Thus, we see that there is a term proportional to L𝐿L that cancels the corresponding term in the residue in Eq. (15), implying that the effective mass is finite.

Indeed, in the low-density few-body regime, we already have the situation where the residue vanishes, while the effective mass remains finite with m∗=(N+1)​msuperscript𝑚𝑁1𝑚m^{*}=(N+1)m, where N𝑁N is the number of bosons bound to to the impurity. This behavior is captured by both r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}- and ΛΛ\Lambda-models, as shown in Fig. 6, where the wave function with two Bogoliubov excitations has m∗/m→3→superscript𝑚𝑚3m^{*}/m\to 3 as n→0→𝑛0n\to 0. Likewise, we expect the wave function with three excitations to recover the mass of the tetramer in this limit. For higher densities, we find that the results of our variational approach become sensitive to the specific model used, as well as to the number of excitations of the ideal BEC considered. Here, in the many-body limit, one requires an infinite number of low-energy excitations to correctly describe the effective mass for aB→0→subscript𝑎B0a_{\text{B}}\to 0, similarly to the case of the residue.

For a BEC with 0<n1/3​aB≪10superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎Bmuch-less-than10<n^{1/3}a_{\text{B}}\ll 1, the behavior of the effective mass in the high-density limit of the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model can once again be captured using just two Bogoliubov excitations of the BEC. In the limit |r0|→∞→subscript𝑟0|r_{0}|\to\infty, the polaron effective mass m∗/m→4/3→superscript𝑚𝑚43m^{*}/m\to 4/3, which corresponds to twice the reduced mass of the impurity and closed-channel dimer. Moreover, we find that the leading order correction behaves as

mm∗−34∝aB|r0|.proportional-to𝑚superscript𝑚34subscript𝑎Bsubscript𝑟0\displaystyle\frac{m}{m^{*}}-\frac{3}{4}\propto\sqrt{\frac{a_{\text{B}}}{|r_{0}|}}. (19)

Thus, the effective mass in this case initially decreases with decreasing density, before increasing towards the mass of the deepest bound few-body cluster.

V.3 Contact

Another quantity of interest is the unitary Tan contact, which is defined from the polaron energy as Tan (2008a); *Tan_2008b; *Tan_2008c; Braaten et al. (2008)

C𝐶\displaystyle C =m2​g2​∂E∂ν|ν=0.absentevaluated-atsuperscript𝑚2superscript𝑔2𝐸𝜈𝜈0\displaystyle=m^{2}g^{2}\left.\frac{\partial E}{\partial\nu}\right|_{\nu=0}. (20)

Here we have used the physical detuning ν≡−g2​m/4​π​a𝜈superscript𝑔2𝑚4𝜋𝑎\nu\equiv-g^{2}m/4\pi a, which can be related to the bare detuning ν0subscript𝜈0\nu_{0} using Eq. (3). Physically, the contact gives a measure of the density of pairs at short distances. For the two-channel Hamiltonian in Eq. (II), one can show that the contact is proportional to the population of closed-channel dimers Braaten et al. (2008):

C𝐶\displaystyle C =m2​g2​∑𝐤⟨Ψ|d𝐤†​d𝐤|Ψ⟩.absentsuperscript𝑚2superscript𝑔2subscript𝐤quantum-operator-productΨsubscriptsuperscript𝑑†𝐤subscript𝑑𝐤Ψ\displaystyle=m^{2}g^{2}\sum_{\bf k}\left\langle{\Psi}\right|d^{\dagger}_{\bf k}d_{\bf k}\left|{\Psi}\right>. (21)

Within our variational ansatz, this corresponds to

C𝐶\displaystyle C =m2​g2​(|γ0|2+∑𝐤|γ𝐤|2+12​∑𝐤1​𝐤2|γ𝐤1​𝐤2|2).absentsuperscript𝑚2superscript𝑔2superscriptsubscript𝛾02subscript𝐤superscriptsubscript𝛾𝐤212subscriptsubscript𝐤1subscript𝐤2superscriptsubscript𝛾subscript𝐤1subscript𝐤22\displaystyle=m^{2}g^{2}\left(|\gamma_{0}|^{2}+\sum_{\bf k}|\gamma_{\bf k}|^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\sum_{{\bf k}_{1}{\bf k}_{2}}|\gamma_{{\bf k}_{1}{\bf k}_{2}}|^{2}\right). (22)

Note that the limit g→∞→𝑔g\to\infty is well defined, and thus this expression also captures the single-channel ΛΛ\Lambda-model.

Figure 7 displays the contact at unitarity for both ΛΛ\Lambda- and r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-models in the case of vanishing boson-boson interactions. Similarly to the polaron energy, we find that the contact in the high-density limit is well converged with respect to the number of Bogoliubov excitations. For the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model, we can evaluate the contact perturbatively for large n1/3​|r0|superscript𝑛13subscript𝑟0n^{1/3}|r_{0}| using the self-energy in Eq. (12). Here we simply shift the closed-channel dispersion from ϵ𝐩dsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐩𝑑\epsilon_{\bf p}^{d} to ϵ𝐩d+νsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐩𝑑𝜈\epsilon_{\bf p}^{d}+\nu and then determine the ground-state energy from the equation E=Σ​(𝟎,E)𝐸Σ0𝐸E=\Sigma({\bf 0},E) as a function of detuning ν𝜈\nu. Applying Eq. (20) then yields the high-density expression

C≃8​π|r0|​(12−2928​37​1(8​π​n​|r0|3)1/4).similar-to-or-equals𝐶8𝜋subscript𝑟0122928371superscript8𝜋𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑟0314\displaystyle C\simeq\frac{8\pi}{|r_{0}|}\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{29}{28}\sqrt{\frac{3}{7}}\frac{1}{(8\pi n|r_{0}|^{3})^{1/4}}\right). (23)

We find that this perturbative result is correctly reproduced by both two- and three-excitation approximations in the high-density limit. The leading order term is independent of density since the closed-channel fraction tends to 1/2121/2 at unitarity as |r0|→∞→subscript𝑟0|r_{0}|\to\infty (or, equivalently, as g→0→𝑔0g\to 0), see Eq. (15).

For lower densities n1/3​|a−|≲103less-than-or-similar-tosuperscript𝑛13subscript𝑎superscript103n^{1/3}|a_{-}|\lesssim 10^{3}, the contact becomes insensitive to the underlying model and thus appears to be a universal function of the dimensionless three-body parameter (see Fig. 7). In the limit of vanishing density n→0→𝑛0n\to 0, we recover the contact of the deepest bound few-body cluster, where C​|a−|𝐶subscript𝑎C|a_{-}| is a universal number.

VI Conclusions and outlook

Using a variational approach, we have investigated the ground state of the Bose polaron with unitarity limited impurity-boson interactions. For sufficiently low boson densities, we have demonstrated that the polaron equation of state is a universal function of the three-body parameter associated with Efimov physics. This is a highly non-trivial result, since the regime of universality extends to densities at which the binding energies of the few-body states are several orders of magnitude smaller than the polaron energy. Our findings are corroborated by the fact that we observe the same behavior for two different microscopic models, and by the fact that our calculations agree well with recent QMC results Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2015, 2016) when they are appropriately reinterpreted in terms of the three-body parameter. We have also demonstrated that the few-body spectrum of Efimov trimers and associated tetramers is model independent, further highlighting the universality of our results.

In the non-universal, high-density limit, we have performed a controlled perturbative analysis of the r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model and we have derived new analytic expressions for the unitary Bose polaron at a narrow Feshbach resonance. Our results demonstrate that even when we take the ideal Bose gas limit, the polaron energy and contact can remain well defined thermodynamically. This is a consequence of the fact that only one boson at a time can occupy the closed-channel dimer state, which thus generates an effective repulsion between bosons that acts to stabilize the system. We expect a similar scenario for the ΛΛ\Lambda-model since the high-momentum cut-off in the three- and four-body terms of the variational equations is equivalent to an explicit three-body repulsion Bedaque et al. (1999). However, in general, it is not clear that a well-defined thermodynamic limit exists for treatments of the Bose polaron that focus on single-channel Hamiltonians and neglect Efimov physics Shchadilova et al. (2016b); Grusdt et al. (2017).

While the polaron equation of state at unitarity is relatively insensitive to boson-boson interactions, we find that the quasiparticle residue and effective mass strongly depend on the coherence length of the BEC. In particular, the residue vanishes as ξ→∞→𝜉\xi\to\infty, a feature which resembles the orthogonality catastrophe Anderson (1967). Thus, an interesting remaining question is how the residue tends to zero with the number of excitations of the condensate included in the wave function. A related question is: what finite result does the effective mass converge towards as ξ→∞→𝜉\xi\to\infty and is it a universal function of the three-body parameter?

We emphasize that the (two-channel) r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}-model faithfully describes the physics of an actual Feshbach resonance in an ultracold atomic gas Timmermans et al. (1999), and thus we expect our results to accurately describe current and future cold atom experiments. Furthermore, we expect the universal behavior presented here to also exist for heavy impurities, a scenario which can be realized by choosing atomic species with a large mass ratio or by pinning the impurity in an optical lattice. In the particular case of a static impurity, there are no Efimov few-body states, and therefore it would be of great interest to understand how the system behaves in the limit n1/3​|r0|≪1much-less-thansuperscript𝑛13subscript𝑟01n^{1/3}|r_{0}|\ll 1 of the two-channel model.

Our results may be probed in experiments similar to those carried out recently at JILA Hu et al. (2016) and in Aarhus Jørgensen et al. (2016). In particular, our results directly apply to the latter experiment which used 39K as both the impurity and host atoms. Furthermore, we estimate that n1/3​|a−|≃100similar-to-or-equalssuperscript𝑛13subscript𝑎100n^{1/3}|a_{-}|\simeq 100 in that experiment, which indicates that it is already in a regime where the non-trivial dependendence on the interparticle spacing is strongly pronounced. Indeed, in a recent JILA experiement Klauss et al. (2017), the density of the Bose gas was changed by two orders of magnitude, and thus an experimental investigation of the density dependence of the unitary Bose polaron appears well within reach.

Appendix B Effect of finite coherence length and number of Bogoliubov excitations

In Section IV.3 we compared the results of our variational approach with those obtained in quantum Monte Carlo calculations by Peña Ardila and Giorgini Peña Ardila and Giorgini (2016), and found very good agreement across more than an order of magnitude in interparticle spacing, see Fig. 2. In this comparison we highlighted the fact that the dependence of the polaron energy on the three-body parameter a−subscript𝑎a_{-} is much stronger than the dependence on aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}}, and to emphasize this we took aB=0subscript𝑎B0a_{\text{B}}=0. However, as we have argued in Section III, in the QMC calculation the ratio between a−subscript𝑎a_{-} and aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}} was kept fixed at a value of a−(QMC)≃−2.09​(36)×104​aB(QMC)similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptsubscript𝑎QMC2.0936superscript104superscriptsubscript𝑎BQMCa_{-}^{\mathrm{{\scriptscriptstyle(QMC)}}}\simeq-2.09(36)\times 10^{4}a_{\text{B}}^{\rm{\scriptscriptstyle(QMC)}} as identified in Eq. (11). Therefore, we now consider the residual effect of keeping a−/aBsubscript𝑎subscript𝑎Ba_{-}/a_{\text{B}} fixed in the same manner as in the QMC. Our results for the polaron energy within the ΛΛ\Lambda-model are shown in Fig. 8. We see that the polaron energy is almost unaffected in the low-density, few-body dominated regime, while aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}} becomes more important with increasing density. However, throughout the range plotted, i.e., the universal many-body regime, the relative change in energy arising from the change in n1/3​|a−|superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎n^{1/3}|a_{-}| clearly greatly exceeds that from the increase in n1/3​aBsuperscript𝑛13subscript𝑎Bn^{1/3}a_{\text{B}}. We furthermore see that both sets of results are consistent with our reinterpretation of the QMC results in terms of a three-body parameter.

In the inset of Fig. 8 we furthermore illustrate the convergence of the polaron energy as a function of (inverse) number of Bogoliubov excitations included in our variational approach. In the many-body dominated regime, at n1/3​|a−|=500superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎500n^{1/3}|a_{-}|=500, we see that the convergence appears to be nearly linear, with a slope (and extrapolation to an infinite number of excitations) that is consistent with the difference between the finite aBsubscript𝑎Ba_{\text{B}} dotted line and the QMC results in the main figure. Closer to the few-body dominated regime at n1/3​|a−|=100superscript𝑛13subscript𝑎100n^{1/3}|a_{-}|=100 our approach converges more slowly due to the strong few-body correlations induced by the trimer and tetramer bound states. However, it is likely that including four Bogoliubov excitations in our approach to account for the hypothesized pentamer (see Sec. IV.1) would yield a nearly converged result.

C.1 Effective mass

For a system with rotational symmetry, the inverse effective mass is defined as

1m∗=∂2E​(P)∂P2,1superscript𝑚superscript2𝐸𝑃superscript𝑃2\displaystyle\frac{1}{m^{*}}=\frac{\partial^{2}E(P)}{\partial P^{2}}, (36)

where E​(P)𝐸𝑃E(P) is the energy dispersion of the Bose polaron. The variational ansatz can be easily extended to a Bose polaron with a finite momentum, but solving the resulting integral equations becomes numerically expensive because the equations do not have rotational symmetry. Here, following a similar line of argument to Ref. Trefzger and Castin (2012), we present a method to calculate the effective mass without solving the integral equations for a finite-momentum Bose polaron.

In general, the coupled integral equations for γ𝛾\gamma’s for a finite momentum polaron have the following structure (similar to Eqs. (24-27)):

X^​[E​(P),𝐏]​|γ⟩=0.^𝑋𝐸𝑃𝐏ket𝛾0\displaystyle\hat{X}[E(P),{\bf P}]\left|{\gamma}\right>=0. (37)

Here, |γ⟩ket𝛾\left|{\gamma}\right> is an ordered set of γ0subscript𝛾0\gamma_{0}, γ𝐤subscript𝛾𝐤\gamma_{\bf k} and γ𝐤1​𝐤2subscript𝛾subscript𝐤1subscript𝐤2\gamma_{{\bf k}_{1}{\bf k}_{2}}, and the center-of-mass momentum can be taken to be P​𝐞z𝑃subscript𝐞𝑧P{\bf e}_{z} without loss of generality. While the matrix X^^𝑋\hat{X} is not the Hamiltonian, it is still Hermitian. The energy dispersion E​(P)𝐸𝑃E(P) is determined by the zero-crossing of the lowest (or highest, depending on the sign convention) eigenvalue of X^^𝑋\hat{X}. Therefore, for a small P𝑃P, we can expand X^^𝑋\hat{X} up to 𝒪​(P2)𝒪superscript𝑃2{\cal O}(P^{2}) and evaluate the lowest eigenvalue in the same way as the Rayleigh-Schrödinger perturbation theory. It is straightforward to show that

X^​[E​(P),P]=X^0+P​X^P+P22​(X^P​P+(1/m∗)​X^E)+𝒪​(P3),^𝑋𝐸𝑃𝑃subscript^𝑋0𝑃subscript^𝑋𝑃superscript𝑃22subscript^𝑋𝑃𝑃1superscript𝑚subscript^𝑋𝐸𝒪superscript𝑃3\displaystyle\hat{X}[E(P),P]=\hat{X}_{0}+P\hat{X}_{P}+\frac{P^{2}}{2}\left(\hat{X}_{PP}+(1/m^{*})\hat{X}_{E}\right)+{\cal O}(P^{3}), (38)

where

X^0=X^​[E​(0),0],X^P=∂X^∂P​[E,P]|E=E​(0)P=0,X^P​P=∂2X^∂P2​[E,P]|E=E​(0)P=0,X^E=∂X^∂E​[E,P]|E=E​(0)P=0.\displaystyle\hat{X}_{0}=\hat{X}[E(0),0],\quad\hat{X}_{P}=\left.\frac{\partial\hat{X}}{\partial P}[E,P]\right|_{{}_{E=E(0)}^{P=0}},\quad\hat{X}_{PP}=\left.\frac{\partial^{2}\hat{X}}{\partial P^{2}}[E,P]\right|_{{}_{E=E(0)}^{P=0}},\quad\hat{X}_{E}=\left.\frac{\partial\hat{X}}{\partial E}[E,P]\right|_{{}_{E=E(0)}^{P=0}}. (39)

Then the lowest eigenvalue λ​(P)𝜆𝑃\lambda(P) of X^​[E​(P),P]^𝑋𝐸𝑃𝑃\hat{X}[E(P),P] can be expressed as a series expansion in terms of P𝑃P,

λ​(P)=λ0+λ1​P+λ2​P2+𝒪​(P3),𝜆𝑃subscript𝜆0subscript𝜆1𝑃subscript𝜆2superscript𝑃2𝒪superscript𝑃3\displaystyle\lambda(P)=\lambda_{0}+\lambda_{1}P+\lambda_{2}P^{2}+{\cal O}(P^{3}), (40)

and its coefficients λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} are determined perturbatively:

λ1subscript𝜆1\displaystyle\lambda_{1} =⟨γ(0)|X^P|γ(0)⟩=0,absentquantum-operator-productsuperscript𝛾0subscript^𝑋𝑃superscript𝛾00\displaystyle=\left\langle{\gamma^{(0)}}\right|\hat{X}_{P}\left|{\gamma^{(0)}}\right>=0, (41)
λ2subscript𝜆2\displaystyle\lambda_{2} =12​⟨γ(0)|(X^P​P+(1/m∗)​X^E)|γ(0)⟩+∑i>0|⟨γ(i)|X^P|γ(0)⟩|2λ0(0)−λ0(i).absent12quantum-operator-productsuperscript𝛾0subscript^𝑋𝑃𝑃1superscript𝑚subscript^𝑋𝐸superscript𝛾0subscript𝑖0superscriptquantum-operator-productsuperscript𝛾𝑖subscript^𝑋𝑃superscript𝛾02superscriptsubscript𝜆00superscriptsubscript𝜆0𝑖\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}\left\langle{\gamma^{(0)}}\right|\left(\hat{X}_{PP}+(1/m^{*})\hat{X}_{E}\right)\left|{\gamma^{(0)}}\right>+\sum_{i>0}\frac{|\left\langle{\gamma^{(i)}}\right|\hat{X}_{P}\left|{\gamma^{(0)}}\right>|^{2}}{\lambda_{0}^{(0)}-\lambda_{0}^{(i)}}. (42)

Here, λ0(i)subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑖0\lambda^{(i)}_{0} and |γ(i)⟩ketsuperscript𝛾𝑖\left|{\gamma^{(i)}}\right> are the i𝑖i-th eigenvalue and its corresponding eigenvector of X^0subscript^𝑋0\hat{X}_{0}, and i=0𝑖0i=0 corresponds to the state that satisfies X^0​[E​(0),𝟎]​|γ(0)⟩=λ0(0)​|γ(0)⟩=0subscript^𝑋0𝐸00ketsuperscript𝛾0superscriptsubscript𝜆00ketsuperscript𝛾00\hat{X}_{0}[E(0),{\bf 0}]\left|{\gamma^{(0)}}\right>=\lambda_{0}^{(0)}\left|{\gamma^{(0)}}\right>=0. λ1=0subscript𝜆10\lambda_{1}=0 follows from the rotational invariance of |γ(0)⟩ketsuperscript𝛾0\left|{\gamma^{(0)}}\right>. Now, recalling that the energy dispersion is found by zero-crossing of the lowest eigenvalue of X^​[E​(P),P]^𝑋𝐸𝑃𝑃\hat{X}[E(P),P], we can set

λ​(P)=λ0(0)=0,𝜆𝑃superscriptsubscript𝜆000\displaystyle\lambda(P)=\lambda_{0}^{(0)}=0, (43)

which in turn, implies that λ2=0subscript𝜆20\lambda_{2}=0. From this, the inverse effective mass is obtained as follows:
